items.title: She was accused of threatening a former Alberta justice minister, others — until a spoofed email came to light
items.summary_auto: A Calgary woman accused of sending five emails that threatened former Alberta justice minister Jonathan Denis, his mother and several of his friends has seen those charges dropped after evidence was revealed in court that one of the emails was sent through an email-spoofing website based in the Czech Republic and police determined the other four were “not authentic.”

items.title: Warner Bros. asks investors to reject takeover bid from Paramount Skydance
items.summary_auto: Warner Bros. is telling shareholders to reject a takeover bid from Paramount Skydance, saying that a rival bid from Netflix will be better for customers.

items.title: Health experts urge parents not to buy kids e-scooters for Christmas
items.summary_auto: Citing injury risk and little-known laws around private e-scooter usage, emergency department physician Dr. Stephanie VandenBerg says she gives an “unequivocal nay” to gifting e-scooters for Christmas.

items.title: U.S. ski towns hope holiday season marks turnaround after slump in Canadian visitors
Olivia and Noah are most popular baby names in Ontario. Muhammad cracks top 10
items.summary_auto: Olivia and Noah are once again the most popular names for new babies in Ontario, according to a list released by the province on Tuesday. And Muhammad appears for the first time in at least 10 years on the list.

items.title: Setting kids up 'for failure': Child welfare agency raises concerns about Manitoba’s emergency placements
items.summary_auto: Failing to report when a child is missing, sending kids to school in soiled clothes and refusing to learn how to treat a little girl's medical condition are just a few of the concerns being raised by a Manitoba child welfare agency about emergency placement staff.

items.title: Rare instance of polar bear cub being adopted near Churchill, Man., verified by scientists
items.summary_auto: Scientists were recently greeted with a most unexpected surprise when a polar bear mother and her cub were walking near Churchill in mid-November when scientists witnessed the mother adopt a second cub, marking just the 13th such case of cub adoption within the western Hudson Bay study population of northeastern Manitoba.

items.title: Rare instance of polar bear cub being adopted near Churchill verified by scientists
items.summary_auto: Scientists were recently greeted with a most unexpected surprise when a polar bear mother and her cub were walking near Churchill in mid-November when scientists witnessed the mother adopt a second cub, marking just the 13th such case of cub adoption within the western Hudson Bay study population of northeastern Manitoba.

items.title: With American alcohol back on N.S. shelves, here's what people are buying
items.summary_auto: In the first week that American alcohol was back on shelves in the province, the Nova Scotia Liquor Corporation sold about $3 million worth of the products, representing about 20 per cent of the remaining U.S. inventory.

items.title: Under pressure to surrender land to Russia, Zelenskyy pitches a referendum
How ISIS could be linked to the deadly Bondi Beach mass shooting
items.summary_auto: The suspects alleged to have carried out the deadly mass shooting at Sydney's Bondi Beach may have been inspired by ISIS or provided actual training to help carry out the attack, experts of the militant group say.

items.title: Bare trust tax filings on pause again as government mulls exemptions
items.summary_auto: Canada's tax agency says it doesn't expect Canadians who hold simple trusts, known as bare trusts, to file required tax forms this coming tax season — but legislative changes currently before the House of Commons means the requirements will likely be there in 2027.

items.title: Undocumented children fear being stuck in state of limbo that could last years
items.summary_auto: Undocumented youth in Canada say they’re feeling worried and hopeless as they face decades-long processing times for permanent residence under the humanitarian and compassionate pathway. Lawyers fear more children will lose their status in the coming years, forcing them to go underground.

items.title: PQ lead in polls won't last, referendum promise will turn off Quebecers, Legault says
items.summary_auto: François Legault's political future looks bleek. His party is currently projected to win zero seats in the next provincial election. But in a recent interview with Radio-Canada Téléjournal host Patrice Roy, the premier said he believes he will win next October and the Parti Québécois's lead in the polls won't last.

items.title: Jared Kushner no longer part of hostile takeover bid for Warner Bros. Discovery
items.summary_auto: A private equity firm owned by U.S. President Donald Trump's son-in-law, Jared Kushner, is no longer backing Paramount's hostile acquisition bid for Warner Bros. Discovery, the firm confirmed Tuesday.

items.title: #TheMoment boats decked out in Christmas lights lit up the Newfoundland coast
items.summary_auto: Joyce Morgan, chairperson of the Boat Lighting Committee, tells The National about the moment over 50 boats decked out in Christmas lights lit up Port de Grave, N.L.

items.title: 19 more pistachio and pistachio-related products recalled in Canada
items.summary_auto: Nineteen more pistachio and pistachio-containing products have been recalled in Canada.

items.title: Via Rail CEO stepping down as Crown corporation faces increasing scrutiny
Doctors urge vaccinations as flu and RSV cases rise among children in B.C.
items.summary_auto: Health professionals in B.C. are asking parents to be vigilant this respiratory season as ER and primary care centre visits for children surge across the province.

items.title: 'It's really scary': Thousands of people in Newfoundland remain without power after wind storm
items.summary_auto: Residents of Fogo Island, Change Islands and other parts of central Newfoundland remain without power Tuesday evening following hurricane-force gusts, with some areas nearing 20 hours without heat and light.

items.title: Quebec Liberals at a crossroads amid mounting pressure on leader to step down
items.summary_auto: With Quebec Liberal Party Leader Pablo Rodriguez and his party facing an internal crisis for nearly a month, the Journal de Montréal has revealed more allegations of financial schemes during his leadership race. The Liberal caucus says it is behind Rodriguez but if that changes, any dissent could create a domino effect.

items.title: Rockalina the turtle meets member of her own species for the 1st time in 48 years
items.summary_auto: After nearly 50 years living on a kitchen floor in New Jersey and eating a diet of mainly cat food, Rockalina the turtle was in rough shape. But after 11 months of rehabilitation, she's thriving — and she even has an itty-bitty new friend.

items.title: Canada's appeal dismissed in battle over fixing mould in Oneida grandmother’s home
items.summary_auto: The Canadian government has lost in court a second time to a First Nations grandmother fighting to fix extensive mould at her home on Oneida Nation of the Thames, near London, Ont. The decision is the first time the Federal Court of Appeal has considered the legal issues surrounding Jordan's Principle.

items.title: Why officials tested ski wax for 'forever chemicals' at Olympic cross-country trials in B.C.
items.summary_auto: Wax is crucial for athletes' ability to grip and slide on snow, but one previously popular ingredient was banned from all elite competition in recent years.

items.title: 40 people temporarily displaced after fire at former seniors home in western P.E.I.
items.summary_auto: Firefighters received a call about an alarm inside the building Tuesday morning. Crews discovered that the fire broke out in an attic in the centre section of the building.

items.title: An Albertan's fridge got delivered to wrong address. Then police say he grabbed his gun
items.summary_auto: An appliance driver who couldn't change a delivery address got punched. A Sundre man has been charged with 14 offences, including assault and extortion with a firearm.

items.title: Mikaela Shiffrin wins 4th straight slalom of Olympic season as rivals falter in night race
items.summary_auto: American skiing standout Mikaela Shiffrin claimed a record-extending 105th World Cup victory on Tuesday after several of her top challengers went out during the opening run of a women's slalom in Courcheval, France.

items.title: Trump expands U.S. travel ban to 5 more countries and Palestinian Authority, toughens limits on others
items.summary_auto: The Trump administration is expanding its travel ban to include five more countries and impose new limits on others.

items.title: N.B., Ottawa agree to streamline environmental assessments for major projects
items.summary_auto: The federal and New Brunswick provincial governments have signed an agreement to co-ordinate their environmental impact assessments so there is less duplication.

items.title: Trump's chief of staff gives rare interview: Here are 5 things we learned
19-year-old pleads guilty to impaired driving in Toronto crash that killed 3 children
items.summary_auto: The young man accused of being impaired and behind the wheel at the time he slammed into a Toronto family’s van, killing three children, has pleaded guilty in the case.

items.title: 'Buy Canadian' policy comes into effect for federal projects worth over $25M
items.summary_auto: The federal government's "Buy Canadian" policy takes effect Tuesday and Ottawa says it will fundamentally change the way it purchases goods and services.

items.title: Canadian men's ski cross athlete becomes most decorated winner in World Cup history
items.summary_auto: Reese Howden now stands alone as the winningest men's ski cross racer in World Cup history. The Canadian won gold at an event in Arosa, Switzerland, on Tuesday for his 19th career victory on the World Cup circuit. That broke a tie for the most victories by a male athlete in World Cup history, a record Howden had shared with Jean-Frédéric Chapuis of France

items.title: Rob Reiner's son Nick Reiner charged with 2 counts of 1st-degree murder
items.summary_auto: Rob Reiner's son Nick Reiner was charged Tuesday with two counts of first-degree murder in the killing of his parents, which stunned their communities in Hollywood and Democratic politics, where both were widely beloved.

items.title: Chilliwack, B.C., mother killed by falling tree in park amid gale-force winds
items.summary_auto: Police say there is no indication the incident was anything other than a tragic and unforeseen event that occurred during severe and unpredictable weather.
